issues: Elevated creatinine (1.69 mg/dL) indicating renal impairment
Missing BUN values to assess kidney function
Missing BMI data to interpret creatinine accurately
No timestamps for laboratory values, uncertainty about lab recency
Hemodynamic instability (MAP 49.3 mmHg, systolic BP 78 mmHg) increasing risk of contrast‑induced nephropathy
recommendations: Obtain BUN and potassium laboratory measurements before proceeding with contrast
Obtain a recent serum creatinine and confirm eGFR to assess current renal function
Stabilize hemodynamics (raise MAP and systolic BP) before any contrast administration
Consider non‑contrast or alternative imaging modalities if diagnostically sufficient
If contrast is essential, implement aggressive IV hydration and monitor renal function post‑contrast
Document discussion of renal risk, obtain patient consent, and record the mitigation plan
Re‑evaluate after obtaining missing labs and confirming hemodynamic stability
